snippet.textDisplay:
One of the main foundations of the franchise, not one of the first games on it (so maybe not as classic as they are), but still remains as a pillar of Square and videogame (and entertainment in general) history to date. Plus it has the best intro sequence in ALL of gaming history in my opinion.
(obs: i don't mean the best opening animation ever made, that would be Suikoden III's for me, here i mean the best story introduction to the game, when she goes to Narshe with those two other guys, Biggs and Wedge, the three dressed in robots...).

snippet.textDisplay:
I have kind of a weird story to tell about this game, and this song specifically.
I was 6 years old when I first played Final Fantasy 3/6, I rented it the week it came out back in October of 1994. Now, I've been a huge sports fan my whole life, and the last half of that year _sucked_ for pro sports - the NHL locked out it's players (its season was due to start October 1st, a mere 11 days before FF3/6 came out in America), the MLB's players went on strike, and the NBA's biggest star, Michael Jordan, had retired. Being as young as I was I didn't fully understand _why_ there was no hockey or baseball going on,  I just felt depressed that my favourite sports weren't being played for stupid reasons.

So I saw this game at the video store, rented it, played it, and I heard this song during the opening credits and took to it immediately. It's somber tone, combined with the image of Terra & her 2 captors trekking through the harsh winter night, really appealed to me during that cold, depressing, mostly-sportsless autumn of 1994.
snippet.textOriginal:
I have kind of a weird story to tell about this game, and this song specifically.
I was 6 years old when I first played Final Fantasy 3/6, I rented it the week it came out back in October of 1994. Now, I've been a huge sports fan my whole life, and the last half of that year _sucked_ for pro sports - the NHL locked out it's players (its season was due to start October 1st, a mere 11 days before FF3/6 came out in America), the MLB's players went on strike, and the NBA's biggest star, Michael Jordan, had retired. Being as young as I was I didn't fully understand _why_ there was no hockey or baseball going on,  I just felt depressed that my favourite sports weren't being played for stupid reasons.

So I saw this game at the video store, rented it, played it, and I heard this song during the opening credits and took to it immediately. It's somber tone, combined with the image of Terra & her 2 captors trekking through the harsh winter night, really appealed to me during that cold, depressing, mostly-sportsless autumn of 1994.

snippet.textDisplay:
The ultimate supremacy of Square in 11 years:

1991 - Final Fantasy IV
1992 - Final Fantasy V
1993 - Secret of Mana
1994 - Final Fantasy VI
1995 - Chrono Trigger
1996 - Super Mario RPG
1997 - Final Fantasy VII
1998 - Xenogears
1999 - Final Fantasy VIII
2000 - Vagrant Story/Chrono Cross/Final Fantasy IX
2001 - Final Fantasy X
2002 - Kingdom Hearts

1996 - Super Mario RPG
1997 - Final Fantasy VII
1998 - Xenogears
1999 - Final Fantasy VIII

snippet.textDisplay: +Jacob Carpenter Nobuo Uematsu composed some of the tracks in Chrono Trigger, but it was Yasunori Mitsuda whom composed the majority of the music in Chrono Trigger. Mitsuda also composed music in other fantastic games like Chrono Cross and Xenogears.
snippet.textOriginal: +Jacob Carpenter Nobuo Uematsu composed some of the tracks in Chrono Trigger, but it was Yasunori Mitsuda whom composed the majority of the music in Chrono Trigger. Mitsuda also composed music in other fantastic games like Chrono Cross and Xenogears.

snippet.textDisplay: There are a couple of songs that do not need to be reorchestrated or remastered. They already sound amazing, because they are pushing the consoles to its limit. They sound amazing, even on the SNES/Super Famicom. Terra's theme from Final Fantasy VI is one of those songs. It doesn't even sound like it is from a 16-bit console. The sensation is what it makes it so awesome. Although I do hope Square will remake this game for Wii U, 3DS or PS4/XBOX One.
snippet.textOriginal: There are a couple of songs that do not need to be reorchestrated or remastered. They already sound amazing, because they are pushing the consoles to its limit. They sound amazing, even on the SNES/Super Famicom. Terra's theme from Final Fantasy VI is one of those songs. It doesn't even sound like it is from a 16-bit console. The sensation is what it makes it so awesome. Although I do hope Square will remake this game for Wii U, 3DS or PS4/XBOX One.

snippet.textDisplay:
R3D, let me say this right off the bat: parts 4, 5, 6, 7, and 10 are five of the best games ever made. You can't go wrong with any of them.

My personal favorite is 6, so I'd recommend starting off with that one. That said, a LOT of people who started with 7 became fans of the series. So maybe play those two first. 

Part 9 is really good. I just don't personally like it as much as the 5 above, but it's a great game. 

13 (the first part) is hugely underrated, but I wouldn't suggest it as the game you start off with. Part 8 is probably the least liked in the whole series, and nowhere near as good as 7, but it's still a lot of fun. I think you can enjoy 8 if you have extremely low expectations and just enjoy it for the some of the awesome designs and spells and general gameplay without comparing it to the series classics. 

15 is cool. It honestly doesn't feel that much like a Final Fantasy game, but it's fun.

Part 9 is really good. I just don't personally like it as much as the 5 above, but it's a great game. 

13 (the first part) is hugely underrated, but I wouldn't suggest it as the game you start off with. Part 8 is probably the least liked in the whole series, and nowhere near as good as 7, but it's still a lot of fun. I think you can enjoy 8 if you have extremely low expectations and just enjoy it for the some of the awesome designs and spells and general gameplay without comparing it to the series classics. 

15 is cool. It honestly doesn't feel that much like a Final Fantasy game, but it's fun.

snippet.textDisplay:
+R3D A good one for begginer's is FF X. After that you should go with FF VI on the GBA emulator with the graphics and sound fix (I'll provide you with everything if you want me to) and after that try the steam version of FF 7 (If you want good graphics mods I'll provide links for those too but I suggest you play the normal version to get the experiences as we got it all those years ago).
•Then, if you like these games play 4, then 3 also on Steam.
•Or if you want more casual but enjoyable FF games after the ones I mentioned first play FF 13-2 (it's a masterpiece but the story is a mess), and then FF 12 (its story is good-ish but the real seller is the HUGE world, the rich world, the well made quests and the fast and strategic combat system that makes you feel like a general).

Happy questing. ;)

snippet.textDisplay: @rtc7788 I think I enjoyed 8 so much because of the way the Guardian Force (summons) and junction system was implemented.  It was really in-depth with the way you could invest in the GF's and junction them and magic to your characters.  You could essentially make god-like characters pretty early if you spent the time to find and draw tons of magic from enemies and draw points.  The draw system is a bit tedious I admit, but the game never forces you to spend asinine amounts of time drawing magic.  Also, I think Triple Triad was my favorite mini game, though some of the quests related to it (namely, the Queen of Cards quest line) were a bit outlandish.  The characters and story were a bit meh, especially for Final Fantasy standards, but it was the other stuff that really drew me into the game.
snippet.textOriginal: @rtc7788 I think I enjoyed 8 so much because of the way the Guardian Force (summons) and junction system was implemented.  It was really in-depth with the way you could invest in the GF's and junction them and magic to your characters.  You could essentially make god-like characters pretty early if you spent the time to find and draw tons of magic from enemies and draw points.  The draw system is a bit tedious I admit, but the game never forces you to spend asinine amounts of time drawing magic.  Also, I think Triple Triad was my favorite mini game, though some of the quests related to it (namely, the Queen of Cards quest line) were a bit outlandish.  The characters and story were a bit meh, especially for Final Fantasy standards, but it was the other stuff that really drew me into the game.

snippet.textDisplay: My first exposure was VI on SNES (III at that time of course).  I never owned it though and had never completed the game since it is a fairly long game.  Though I have played the game since, I usually get caught up in something else before getting to the end.  Although many will probably say otherwise, I think VIII was amazing and I have completed it on numerous occasions.  It was the first Final Fantasy I was able to purchase on release and thus became obsessed with it.  I did enjoy VII a lot, but because I owned VIII I ended up playing it much more and I think it was always my favorite.  I think each entry has its own merits.  VI was the story and character development, VII was Sephiroth, VIII was the Guardian Force and junction system.  I've completed nearly every entry in the main series, but these were the ones I enjoy most.  I think VI can be considered the magnum opus of the series, so start there would be my suggestion.  Just my thoughts, play whichever one you want, or none at all.  OR ALL OF THEM!  DO IT!
snippet.textOriginal: My first exposure was VI on SNES (III at that time of course).  I never owned it though and had never completed the game since it is a fairly long game.  Though I have played the game since, I usually get caught up in something else before getting to the end.  Although many will probably say otherwise, I think VIII was amazing and I have completed it on numerous occasions.  It was the first Final Fantasy I was able to purchase on release and thus became obsessed with it.  I did enjoy VII a lot, but because I owned VIII I ended up playing it much more and I think it was always my favorite.  I think each entry has its own merits.  VI was the story and character development, VII was Sephiroth, VIII was the Guardian Force and junction system.  I've completed nearly every entry in the main series, but these were the ones I enjoy most.  I think VI can be considered the magnum opus of the series, so start there would be my suggestion.  Just my thoughts, play whichever one you want, or none at all.  OR ALL OF THEM!  DO IT!

snippet.textDisplay: Personally, I wasn't a big fan of this game. The storyline is barely there. Kefka makes no sense (he has almost no involvement in the story and is a massive deus ex machina at the end that is never explained.) The individual character plots are good though (particularly locke and celes) and the music is good. My personal favorite FF games will always be 9, 10, and 7 though (with tactics as a close runner up).

snippet.textDisplay:
@kingofbudokai  Kefka had little screen time because unlike most villians he BECAME main villian. Innitially we fought agaist emperor, then Kefka taken over the possition by killing emperor, and destroying the world. It was plot twist, not deus ex machina, since we knew Kefka earlier, he didn't appear out of nowhere, merely his role radically changed. When we met him earlier he seemed like one more of emperors paws to beat on the way to main villian, we knew him well enough to understand what kind of person he is, but not enough for him to look important. It wasn't bad writing it was planned this way. You may or may not like the way it happened, but that doesn't mean it's bad.
PS. I'm not sure why you compare Seymour with Kefka, when Seymour wasn't even close to being the main villian. Seymour was basically Ultros with backstory in terms of game role.

snippet.textDisplay:
@kingofbudokai While I do agree he's pretty one-dimensional, he's by no means a bad villain/character. He hates everything, that's his standout character trait, to a maniacal and sociopathic extent. You don't interact very much with him because either you're travelling in his wake, you're being chased by him/the empire or you're searching for the same thing on different paths. He gets a decent build up since everything he does is shown in cutscenes and (at least, for me) that motivated me to play even more just so I could bash his head in at a later point in the game. He's insane, does horrible things without reason and then brags about them while planning to destroy the world. 

When I think about it; fuck two-dimensional villains, it's way more satisfying to beat them to a pulp when there's no reason to sympathize afterwards.

snippet.textDisplay: @Parhy Lolzilla I'm not sure you know what "deus ex machina" actually means. He is a "Deus ex machina" villain because he gets suddenly dropped into the 'main villain' role at the end with no warning. you don't even really ever meet him until after he becomes a god. That's why I said what I did. You are never given a legitimate reason behind why he is the main villain other than 'he became a god so now you have to kill him', and that's not good enough. You don't have any real interaction with him before that point. even final fantasy 1 had more of a story behind it's final boss than that. As I said, the individual character stories are good, but the overall cohesive plot is very lackluster compared to other games.

snippet.textDisplay: This was the first game that made me cry. Srsly, when I was like 8 years old back in 1995, I was siting in front of my snes (wich I still have) crying salty tears of sadness because of Kefka being an asshole with everybody. Now, almost 20 years have passed and I am still whistling the melody while walking around and stuff. I never had this feels again with video games now a days. Most of them made me feel like: meh, whatevs yo..

snippet.textDisplay:
@***** Hehe, true! Same for me : ) I have a lot of games on my PC, some of them where expensive, some of them weren't and I have a lot of fun with all of them! But the game I spend the most time with is a retro style game called starbound. I don't know, but the pixel and the simple make up of these kind of games always reminds me of my childhood. It gives me the feelings back I had when I was a kid, not worrying about anything, when the world was "alright" and everything was new and exciting... if you know what I mean : ) 

Anyway, really appreciated having a chat with you! You to have a great day!

Anthony

snippet.textDisplay:
@***** I am totally feeling you there! I do play all kind of modern games : ) And I am truely having a blast with most of them! I play everything from racing, adventure, strategy, fps, beat em up, fighting, soccer, sandbox, horror, surviving, open world mmos etc. games. I even bought myself a 5k dollar gaming pc instead of a car in order to enjoy my games properly (yes, I have priorities ^.^ ). My GF is also into all that stuff and I honestly believe I couldn't be with a woman who doesn't understand how important all this is for me. Let's say, I really, really appreciate the next gen, innovativ stuff and all but give me a snes with Terranigma, Chrono Triggers or  FF6 and I will be the happiest guy in my disctrict : ) 

Modern games sure have their qualities. If not, no one would be playing them, and I think game industries always adapt themselves to the standard of their current target audience wich are the 12+ years old of these days, because the 12 year olds from back then are now grown ups and adults and games where mostly orientated to a younger audience even though many adults play games... well maybe because they did when  they were young.... You get my point, mate : )

snippet.textDisplay:
When i first played this game, I was already in tears and determination. Never had a game driven me to want to battle against the asshole Kefka. I’ve played numerous nintendo ported games(besides mario), and this stands out from Zelda and metroid, because the story was SO rich and meaningful and really related to the player in some way. Zelda was just refinding the master sword and Metroid was kill Ridley to avenge your parents. But no wonder FF6 was one of the best selling games of its franchise. 
Also did I mention the attempt of a perspective view of the world map? Badass developers of 1994

When i first played this game, I was already in tears and determination. Never had a game driven me to want to battle against the asshole Kefka. I’ve played numerous nintendo ported games(besides mario), and this stands out from Zelda and metroid, because the story was SO rich and meaningful and really related to the player in some way. Zelda was just refinding the master sword and Metroid was kill Ridley to avenge your parents. But no wonder FF6 was one of the best selling games of its franchise. 
Also did I mention the attempt of a perspective view of the world map? Badass developers of 1994

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm not sure if it's the best since I haven't played all of the FFs (and am in the process). A couple of my friends had a long ass conversation once about how they like 7 better and it's the best game in the series. But what I CAN say is that 6 was really F-ing good. My favorite so far casue it was so f-ing good. Working on finishing 7 and 8 now.

I'm past the part where Aeris dies in 7 (so just reached part 2) and even though it was one of the best parts of the game so far and really sad, I think 6 had a much more melancholic feeling to the game as a whole and that's what made it so good. Just take this song for example. I think it's a fitting song for the whole game, much less just Terra.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm not a huge RPG fan (I get easily bored with the turn based combat) the nostalgia factor got me through FFVII and I did love it. Recently I started playing FFVI and it has awesome OST and it has aged fantastically (not a fan of the gameplay but that's simply because of my opinion towards turn-based combat). FFVII looks terrible nowadays. The polygons have aged badly. I wouldn't actually mind if SE made a 2D remake of FFVII.

snippet.textDisplay: Play it. You're given a short and sweet synopsis once you start a new game. Basically, a corrupt empire is reviving a force that once sparked a war that lasted 1000 years. But the emperor's plans are thrown astray by his sadistic number one, who has his eyes set on becoming a god. Amazing soundtrack, compelling characters, and classic style gameplay to boot. If it weren't for Chrono Trigger, this would easily be my favorite retro RPG.
snippet.textOriginal: Play it. You're given a short and sweet synopsis once you start a new game. Basically, a corrupt empire is reviving a force that once sparked a war that lasted 1000 years. But the emperor's plans are thrown astray by his sadistic number one, who has his eyes set on becoming a god. Amazing soundtrack, compelling characters, and classic style gameplay to boot. If it weren't for Chrono Trigger, this would easily be my favorite retro RPG.

snippet.textDisplay: Just to comment on this, yes games are just as good as they were back then but just in different ways. Instead of developing interesting characters in completely unknown/fantasy-like settings, graphics limited us now to realistic backgrounds. Games now focus on creating a world and overall narrative, whereas a game like Final Fantasy 6 saw almost 90% of its success from character development and competent storytelling. Also, Skyward Sword was probably the most story-driven Zelda to date, Diablo 3 has a TERRIBLE STORY. I'm sorry but when I saw the ending to act 3 I had to stop playing. It made me that mad because they did so good up until then, Kingdom Hearts has far too convoluted for its own good too and has made death about as meaningless as it is in DBZ.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Prince alucard Okay you obviously know NOTHING of how a video game is developed. 
A. It's their biggest cash cow they'd never let it die. If you knew anything about Final Fantasy, you'd know the series holds a very special place in Square Enix's heart. Final Fantasy literally saved that company, it was supposed to be the last game the company ever made. If it weren't for that series, Square Enix wouldn't exist today. It's like telling Nintendo to quit making Mario games because they haven't been that good lately. It won't happen.


B. Writing in the video game industry has been taken completely backstage now. Often how games will be made is like this. An idea for a specific mechanic (like a portal gun for example) will be proposed. The game is made around this mechanic, and then once the game is designed and fleshed out THEN the writers write a story for it. It's one of the last things done next to voice acting. Writing for video games nowadays is like writing a picture prompt where you only get to see half the picture. It's NOT an easy task even for the most skilled writer.


C. Yes they have A LOT of money, but another major failure like FF14 would completely destroy the company. Or any company for that matter. They've stated this themselves, if another massive game like FF14 failed, they would be finished, done, gone. Hell the company that makes Assassin's Creed SPECIFICALLY stated that they will no longer make ANY game they do not believe will become a franchise. Microsoft needs Titanfall to be successful for the Xbox, and are putting so much faith in it, that they ARE LITERALLY MODIFYING THEIR CONTROLLERS specifically for that particular game. Companies depend on the success of one game quite heavily now regardless of however much money they have.


D. Development time is a problem for every company. Therefore you want to time it so every company has a major release at least once a year. Games take at minimum a year to develop. Often that isn't even enough time. You ever try to make a video game? Hell even a flash movie?! Do you have any idea how long a good quality sprite movie could take? MONTHS, and all the materials for that are already there and already made for you. Imagine making a video game from scratch. Look at fan-made hacks nowadays, the better ones are 4-5 years in the making still. =/

snippet.textDisplay:
It's true the cost for video games is dramatic, and that graphics may be slowly killing the franchise of consoles. The industry itself is undergoing a change though. Look at the games that do make it big, all of the indie titles that have gone from games nobody would've heard of to some of the best games we have. Like it or not, the industry is evolving and changing and adapting to the technologies we most rely on such as phones and computers. Consoles probably will always have a place but that aspect of the industry is slowly shrinking due to games being too expensive and time consuming to make.

  
@Prince alucard Imagine being a developer at Square Enix for the next Final Fantasy game. Your game has to look immaculate. The graphics MUST be perfect. Your story has to be solid and match these graphics. The gameplay has to be new and innovative. The writing and dialogue and delivery have to be soul wrenching theatrics. Seriously dude, lay off them. Being a developer company now is very difficult. One bad game can end an entire company. You try being a game developer before you judge.

snippet.textDisplay:
I remember playing FFVI for the first time. I'd actually received the cartridge a good three years before I could play it- my second cousin had given me an NES and a big box of games, which for some reason included FFVI even though he hadn't given me an SNES. The game sat on my shelf for years, building my anticipation every time I saw it, until I finally got my Super Nintendo 3 years later.

I booted up the game, heard this song, and immediately though, "this is the best game ever made."

snippet.textDisplay: I think Square SHOULD NOT remake this game, since they would probably butcher it anyway. What they SHOULD do is make a new game that has a Tales of Vesperia-like battle system and tells a compelling story that has as many plot twists as possible. Remaking a game would do nothing more than be retelling a plot that's already known by every Final Fantasy fan in the world.

snippet.textDisplay: FFVI has good, simple gameplay mechanics (sure, Speed's kinda worthless but whatever), distinct character skill sets and for Final Fantasy, quite enjoyable combat and character development overall. And of course you play games for the story. An RPG without a good story isn't worth playing; story makes characters and RPG is about characters and character development so story is everything. Bad story = bland, uninteresting characters = bad RPG (see e.g. Final Fantasy VIII).

snippet.textDisplay: Different strokes for different folks, to be sure, but I'm perfectly okay with the dubbing of foreign games so long as the dub is well done (I think the dubs of Persona 3 and 4, as well as Tales of the Abyss and Vesperia were good). What annoys me is when they remove voice acting entirely. In Smash Brothers Melee they just took out all the voice clips Mewtwo had, and the second half of Tales of Legendia has no voice acting at all save for the anime cutscenes.
snippet.textOriginal: Different strokes for different folks, to be sure, but I'm perfectly okay with the dubbing of foreign games so long as the dub is well done (I think the dubs of Persona 3 and 4, as well as Tales of the Abyss and Vesperia were good). What annoys me is when they remove voice acting entirely. In Smash Brothers Melee they just took out all the voice clips Mewtwo had, and the second half of Tales of Legendia has no voice acting at all save for the anime cutscenes.

snippet.textDisplay: Becoming motherly makes sense if you really think about it. Being forced together with Hope while he was going through an emotional crisis made her realize just how empty her life had become by pushing everyone who loved her away, and she decided that she would save Hope from her path by helping him in his time of need. She, being older than Hope, naturally assumed a motherly role when Hope needed one to protect Hope, and help Snow with his guilt by having Hope come to terms with the situation..

snippet.textDisplay: This is definitely the best final fantasy game hands down. Final fantasy 6 is the only one in the series that had such a unique twist to its ending that no one imagined. I also loved how it almost felt like you bonded and learned each characters strength and weaknesses in the game with the passing time. You truly felt like that character was part of your team. Most will forever debate about FF4, FF6, and FF7 as the top games tho and like many they are my top 3 out of all the FF games.
snippet.textOriginal: This is definitely the best final fantasy game hands down. Final fantasy 6 is the only one in the series that had such a unique twist to its ending that no one imagined. I also loved how it almost felt like you bonded and learned each characters strength and weaknesses in the game with the passing time. You truly felt like that character was part of your team. Most will forever debate about FF4, FF6, and FF7 as the top games tho and like many they are my top 3 out of all the FF games.

snippet.textDisplay: neither is better, in terms of characters, story, and plot. However, I will concede that 6 is better in terms of overall gameplay, as they used a tried-and-true(at the time) graphics system that didn't need to compensate itself with weird and often glitched gimmicks, and in 6 the movement system was better and more accurate(not bumping into walls all the time). Both games have their merits and shortcomings, but to me they will both be amazing games that I will spend weeks at a time replaying.
snippet.textOriginal: neither is better, in terms of characters, story, and plot. However, I will concede that 6 is better in terms of overall gameplay, as they used a tried-and-true(at the time) graphics system that didn't need to compensate itself with weird and often glitched gimmicks, and in 6 the movement system was better and more accurate(not bumping into walls all the time). Both games have their merits and shortcomings, but to me they will both be amazing games that I will spend weeks at a time replaying.

snippet.textDisplay: i don't see how ff7 is any more repetitive than ff6. both are very story driven, both have random battles, the active time battle system, and your typical melodramatic jrpg story. they are both jrpgs that follow the same basic formula of story sequence -> battle -> explore -> battle -> repeat. to say that ff7 was repetitive is to basically state every ff game to be repetitive, including 6.
snippet.textOriginal: i don't see how ff7 is any more repetitive than ff6. both are very story driven, both have random battles, the active time battle system, and your typical melodramatic jrpg story. they are both jrpgs that follow the same basic formula of story sequence -> battle -> explore -> battle -> repeat. to say that ff7 was repetitive is to basically state every ff game to be repetitive, including 6.

(Although you'd probably all shoot me if I said I liked 'Born Anew' better than 'One Winged Angel')
snippet.textOriginal: I personally liked the soundtrack of XIII. Not to say this one isn't good, it IS great, but if there's one thing XIII did right, it was graphical quality, and its musical score. snippet.textDisplay: I get what ff12 was trying to do, something along the lines of star wars/hidden fortress, where the "lead" characters were merely observers to the grand story, but it doesn't work in a video game, where it's all about immersion, you ARE the lead character in video games,  you generally have to be the be all end all character in a game. The shift from the usual end-of-the-world story to warring nations and kingdoms was a mature and welcome addition though. ff12 had the best production value.

snippet.textDisplay: The thing about FF, it isn't supposed to stay the same, look at what happened with VIII, XII, and XIII. They branch out and try to change up the formula in different ways, are they successful? Thats a whole other issue. But the point is that the series doesn't stagnate on the "successful" formula, it grows and changes, believe it or not some fans hated the change from VI to VII. The series won't die, it just keeps changing, maybe we don't like the change but maybe we'll like the next one.
snippet.textOriginal: The thing about FF, it isn't supposed to stay the same, look at what happened with VIII, XII, and XIII. They branch out and try to change up the formula in different ways, are they successful? Thats a whole other issue. But the point is that the series doesn't stagnate on the "successful" formula, it grows and changes, believe it or not some fans hated the change from VI to VII. snippet.textDisplay:
I've heard from many people, especially FF fans, that this game was the best of the entire series.

But before I go ahead and get it on the Playstation Network, I'd like a second opinion.

At the time of this comment, my two favourite titles in the series are IX and XII. I'll only go for number VI if it''s at least as good as those two.

So here's my question.

Is it?

snippet.textDisplay:
this game was bloody brilliant neither because kefka destroys the whole world or because kefka was unbelievable as a villain, but because -- and for the first time -- you cared about the outcome. terra you care about, the locke and celes romance you care about, elena and his pop, you about -- they became characters with real concerns about whom you cared. for the first time. cecil & rosa wasn't real; this was real. that resonated.

VG culture has gotten away from that.

snippet.textDisplay: @wh15p3r they are not rpg enough for my likes. They are action adventure games with some light rpg elements. Even Zelda II wasn't a full fledged rpg. The games have statistical ways of defeating each enemy (different or stronger weapons may be needed, some need a certain number of hits to defeat). That and some upgrades are about all the series has for rpg elements, but lots of adventure games have that, so I consider it to be a light rpg. It's not turn based or anything, etc.
snippet.textOriginal: @wh15p3r they are not rpg enough for my likes. They are action adventure games with some light rpg elements. Even Zelda II wasn't a full fledged rpg. The games have statistical ways of defeating each enemy (different or stronger weapons may be needed, some need a certain number of hits to defeat). That and some upgrades are about all the series has for rpg elements, but lots of adventure games have that, so I consider it to be a light rpg. It's not turn based or anything, etc.

snippet.textDisplay: So for the past 8 months I've been studying orchestration and composition... 8-10 hours a day. Since I began I've for some reason never gone back to my favorite music of all time. I'm so relieved that even with a deeper understanding of music, this piece still shines as brilliant. Even though it's an ancient digitalized song... the arrangement clearly tells the story. A marching rhythm, with melancholy chords and melody. It gives a sense of reluctantly moving forward.
snippet.textOriginal: So for the past 8 months I've been studying orchestration and composition... 8-10 hours a day. Since I began I've for some reason never gone back to my favorite music of all time. I'm so relieved that even with a deeper understanding of music, this piece still shines as brilliant. Even though it's an ancient digitalized song... the arrangement clearly tells the story. A marching rhythm, with melancholy chords and melody. It gives a sense of reluctantly moving forward.

snippet.textDisplay: @Iconoclast6750 To add to your response, I think FF lost its way in large part to the advance in graphics. FF XIII for example is gorgeous, but so much effort has to be put into that sort of graphical level that story and game play tend to get neglected. I am fine with the developers not always "pleasing the fans:" people gotta take risks. But there is so little effort put on plot, and the symbolic inversions tend to be obvious in the more recent games.
snippet.textOriginal: @Iconoclast6750 To add to your response, I think FF lost its way in large part to the advance in graphics. FF XIII for example is gorgeous, but so much effort has to be put into that sort of graphical level that story and game play tend to get neglected. I am fine with the developers not always "pleasing the fans:" people gotta take risks. But there is so little effort put on plot, and the symbolic inversions tend to be obvious in the more recent games.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem with the final fantasy series is it has lost it's way because it's always under a different design team.. Back then, it had a much smaller budget and the same design team, and they knew what they wanted to do with the game.. Now, with so many different people working on it, someone always has to make it what THEY want it to be instead of pleasing the fans and emulate a mix of the new and old that the fans want..
snippet.textOriginal: The problem with the final fantasy series is it has lost it's way because it's always under a different design team.. Back then, it had a much smaller budget and the same design team, and they knew what they wanted to do with the game.. Now, with so many different people working on it, someone always has to make it what THEY want it to be instead of pleasing the fans and emulate a mix of the new and old that the fans want..

snippet.textDisplay: @DeM0Nf1LmZ You are partially correct, Final Fantasy VI was released in America as Final Fantasy III Because 3-4-5 had not been released to the American public at that time. But Final Fantasy VI (III) Was released as Final Fantasy VI upon the Release of Final Fantasy Anthology Which Also included the American Release of Final Fantasy V for the Sony PlayStation on September 30, 1999 The Next version would have been the Nintendo Gameboy Advanced which was released on February 5, 2007.

snippet.textDisplay:
@kinkkku Part2 for my last comment....

FF12 had a new battle system, which was cool for the first few hours of the game. Then i started to miss all the strategies i always made in the old games to beat the bosses. In FF12 it seemed to be all about running away and healing whenever you can. No more potions to zombies. No more killing monsters in 12 turns just to avoid giga gravija. All bosses also had pretty much immunity to everything. Gameplay, gameplay, gameplay, Its all about gameplay.
snippet.textOriginal:
@kinkkku Part2 for my last comment....

FF12 had a new battle system, which was cool for the first few hours of the game. Then i started to miss all the strategies i always made in the old games to beat the bosses. In FF12 it seemed to be all about running away and healing whenever you can. No more potions to zombies. No more killing monsters in 12 turns just to avoid giga gravija. All bosses also had pretty much immunity to everything. Gameplay, gameplay, gameplay, Its all about gameplay.

snippet.textDisplay: I remember playing this game when it came out. I remember playing the remake watching the mechs walk in the snow with this playing. Today I listen to this and I wonder how it is that we had the formula right back then: Great gameplay + Great Story + Great Soundtrack = Great Game. Somehow between the then and now we have FUBAR'd that formula and leave people wondering when will we get back to the basics?

snippet.textDisplay: @djsilverline69 I find it funny that you think a tiny percentage of nostalgia-blinded "fans" want SE to go back to that archaic, antiquated, inadequate excuse of a combat system that old-gen Final Fantasy games had. snippet.textDisplay:
I have so many fond memories of this game, and I never even got to play it until 5 years ago. 

There are very few games that make you feel like you were making a difference for a world that was all but destroyed, and that your actions had tangible benefits to the people (in spite of the fact that they were just pixels on a screen). FFVI, Wind Waker and a few others come to mind.

So many times I have seen a relationship that was only hinted at in games, which felt all the better for the fact that other people couldn't see it e.g. the relationship between Celes and Locke, which is never explicitly mentioned. However, in modern games, developers are so worried we might miss something, they will give us a total of about 50 minutes of characters staring lovingly into each others eyes! Developers: We are not all slack jawed idiots!

snippet.textDisplay: @djsilverline69 I agree with your sentiments--- Square-Enix, along with most of the other Japanese companies making RPGs these days, have done much to ruin the genre by turning their games into animated Japanese dramas.  It is so annoying to hear the overly melodramatic voice acting and expressions, with cliche Oricon billboard J-pop ballad hit number 6 playing in the background.  It's disgusting.  So many JRPG background scores now also emulate movie scores. It's the wrong direction.
snippet.textOriginal: @djsilverline69 I agree with your sentiments--- Square-Enix, along with most of the other Japanese companies making RPGs these days, have done much to ruin the genre by turning their games into animated Japanese dramas.  It is so annoying to hear the overly melodramatic voice acting and expressions, with cliche Oricon billboard J-pop ballad hit number 6 playing in the background.  It's disgusting.  So many JRPG background scores now also emulate movie scores. It's the wrong direction.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is a final fantasy game that suits everyone.

There is active free roaming battles like FF12
MMO for the world of warcraft type players FF11 & FF14 (btw not into MMOs)
Cyber punk with bad ass move sets FF7, FF13, FF6
Classic traditional FF1, FF3, FF4, FF5, FF2 and FF9

All FF games have their own style of leveling up characters, inventories, battle systems.

As much as I love the old ones to bits, I have a huge love for FF13, its alot faster than the other games.

@djsilverline69 Except the fact that FF13 has some wonderful music (i.e. every battle theme in the game, Lightning, Hope and Sazh's themes), fun and very fast-paced gameplay, and loads and loads of emotion. snippet.textDisplay: I have to say, I don't particularly mind the new FF's. But when it comes down to me thinking, "Hmm, which game should I play again?" My mind never even crosses to 10 on up. As much as I enjoyed ten and all that. I prefer the ones where my imagination filled in the blanks. Such as their voices, their emotions, It's always a toss up between 4-9....I'm never sure which wonderful adventure i'd like to go on again. I miss that.

snippet.textDisplay: @Painkiller1189 Sadly, this seems to be the course of the medium that is computer games. There seems to be an increasing demand for better graphics. What people don't see is that this also exponentially increases developement time and also limits the gameplay. There are even people who say that adding spoken dialogues in games limits the game for you can't flesh out unimportant characters as well. An example is Oblivion, where many NPCs sounded the same. Though this last opinion isn't mine.

snippet.textDisplay: @obyinlondon I have.  Couldn't even finish it.  Only about 3 of the characters seemed interesting. @MySonOfSam  more realistic characters (no machine gun arms, no watermelon sized boobs) and more dramatic storyline; better character development; better music.

snippet.textDisplay: @ColonelxButtFuck I still prefer Terra. Don't take me wrong I love Cecil as a main character and all, but he sometimes was very predictable in the way he acted. If it weren't for the whole "bad turned good" thing, he would be kinda cliche'd and bland. snippet.textDisplay: @TheCritizen FFVII for example didn't adjust to the masses. It made that style popular. The dystopian, cyper-punk look. Also, the gothic/emo look of the Sephiroth character wasn't in the commercial back then. People tend to see the game in a emo type way. But if they actually played the game, and not just watch fan made music videos of Advent Children, they would find that FFVII had much more to do with Blade Runner, or Mad Max. It was truly original.
snippet.textOriginal: @TheCritizen FFVII for example didn't adjust to the masses. It made that style popular. The dystopian, cyper-punk look. Also, the gothic/emo look of the Sephiroth character wasn't in the commercial back then. People tend to see the game in a emo type way. But if they actually played the game, and not just watch fan made music videos of Advent Children, they would find that FFVII had much more to do with Blade Runner, or Mad Max. It was truly original.

@NiMiJoKaONVaPaa That's how I played the older ones too.

snippet.textDisplay:
this is fuckn nostalgic.  I'm crying right now...so..beautiful..  hehe. jk
This is the only FF game where every character matters (xcept maybe Gogo and Umaro, but they are neat enough to be cool).  There is a central simple story, but the best stories are how the characters all interconnected.  Their dynamic with one another is RPG at its best.  The only downside is that near the end every character plays about the same once magic powers start to overcome their unique skills.  Still though :)

snippet.textDisplay:
Sit back, close your eyes, and think of walking the world map.  Doesn't even look like the old pixelated landscape that it is, does it?  Memories are strange.   Even though I was looking at a game the whole time, I can perfectly imagine rolling fields before me.  

...then, of course, the screen slams my face into the ground a couple times and I get into a battle.

snippet.textDisplay: @JesusCristo2002 Final Fantasy VI, Final Fantasy IV, Final Fantasy VII and Final Fantasy X. The others have great stories, but are either harder to find these days (especially Final Fantasy V) or I personally wasn't a fan of the battle and magic systems. Anything after X I find is pretty much a waste of time, and in regards to Compilation of VII just stick to the original game, the only other game from it worth playing was never released outside of Japan.
snippet.textOriginal: @JesusCristo2002 Final Fantasy VI, Final Fantasy IV, Final Fantasy VII and Final Fantasy X. The others have great stories, but are either harder to find these days (especially Final Fantasy V) or I personally wasn't a fan of the battle and magic systems. snippet.textDisplay: @josecoxao Why so quick to acknowledge and succumb to your own nostaglia, though?  It's almost like saying we're powerless to perceive games as anything but individual points along a timeline; never removed.  FF7 was my first, but I can't say it was the best in light of that.  And I certainly can't merit it as the best BECAUSE it was my first.  Don't be so small as to constantly perceive a piece through your younger eyes.

Thing is, something like that twist suffers from the law of diminishing returns. That's why FF8 didn't try to top it and no FF game since has done anything similar.

Call of Duty MW2 skirts the line. It killed a lot of protagonists, not just one. If MW3 goes crazy with it, the impact will be completely lost.

snippet.textDisplay:
*melts*

Oh my god.....

So much nostalgia washing over me now.

This is, quite possibly, the single most nostalgic video game for me.  And this theme - being the main overworld theme and all - is at the heart of it.  Everything about this music, and the game (including the colors) continue to linger in the corners of my mind.  So beautiful.

Your taste in music is exceptional, I must say.

snippet.textDisplay: Final Fantasy VI was the best of the Final Fantasies, and the third best RPG ever, behind Chrono Cross and the Kingdom Hearts games. No other game since has dealt with teenage pregnancy, suicide, honor, the loss of ones family, insanity, love, and memory in quite the same way. Every character has a personal tragedy, and each redeems themself in their own way including (Spoiler) possibly comitting suicide. Poignant, epic, and bittersweet, with one of the best soundtracks ever, this game is great.
snippet.textOriginal: Final Fantasy VI was the best of the Final Fantasies, and the third best RPG ever, behind Chrono Cross and the Kingdom Hearts games. snippet.textDisplay: To be honest, I'm more into N64/PS/Sega Saturn era, even though, Snes is still part of my world (childhood times) as it was my first system to own a gaming console and the first games were Donkey Kong, Zelda, Final Fantasy VI, Yoshi Island, F-zero, and R-Type. They were epic and will never be forgotten. I missed those days from Snes/Sega to Gamecube/PS2 generation. Games nowadays it's not the same as it used to be. Mostly because it's about the graphics and not the gameplay/storyline itself.

snippet.textDisplay:
For me:
Graphics- VII. Both were impressive for their time, but VII's FMVs made it more revolutionary.
Music- Tie. I love them both equally.
Gameplay- Tie. They both have a good flow of events.
Battle System- VI. I hate how you're stuck with Cloud all the time in VII.
Story- Tie. The plots have pretty similar structures.
Characters- VI. I love Terra and Kefka better than anyone in VII.
snippet.textOriginal:
For me:
Graphics- VII. Both were impressive for their time, but VII's FMVs made it more revolutionary.
Music- Tie. I love them both equally.
Gameplay- Tie. They both have a good flow of events.
Battle System- VI. I hate how you're stuck with Cloud all the time in VII.
Story- Tie. The plots have pretty similar structures.
Characters- VI. I love Terra and Kefka better than anyone in VII.

snippet.textDisplay:
Alright, I love FF6(3), and can in no way be compared to FF7 as no FF can be compared to one another.

But to say FF7 had no depth is just shallow in itself. I could not have seen more character development on either character of Sephiroth or Cloud. If you really find the story convoluted, then I want to know your definition on what "deep" is. If, as you say, even young children can understand and enjoy the story that is FF7, what is so convoluted about it?
snippet.textOriginal:
Alright, I love FF6(3), and can in no way be compared to FF7 as no FF can be compared to one another.

But to say FF7 had no depth is just shallow in itself. I could not have seen more character development on either character of Sephiroth or Cloud. If you really find the story convoluted, then I want to know your definition on what "deep" is. If, as you say, even young children can understand and enjoy the story that is FF7, what is so convoluted about it?

snippet.textDisplay:
I didn't find the love triangle to be deep at all - very shallow dialog of flirtation between Tifa and Cloud and Aeris and Cloud. The whole Shinra stuff was very convoluted. It's really nothing compared to FF6, which had multiple examples of that kind of stuff all throughout the game.

Cyan's issues with his family's death alone had more depth than anything in FF7.
snippet.textOriginal:
I didn't find the love triangle to be deep at all - very shallow dialog of flirtation between Tifa and Cloud and Aeris and Cloud. The whole Shinra stuff was very convoluted. It's really nothing compared to FF6, which had multiple examples of that kind of stuff all throughout the game.

Cyan's issues with his family's death alone had more depth than anything in FF7.

snippet.textDisplay: And don't forget Advent Children to add to the mess. Ah, a storyline in FF that had subtleties. You don't find that all that often anymore.
snippet.textOriginal: And don't forget Advent Children to add to the mess. Ah, a storyline in FF that had subtleties. You don't find that all that often anymore.

snippet.textDisplay: Well, if you think the story in FF7 was overly complex, maybe you should try the Metal Gear storyline. That will get your juices flowing! CT is my 2nd fave RPG of all time, but FF7 holds memories for me. Cloud-Tifa-Aeris love triangle is complex until Aeris dies, but even after that his emotions for Aeris grew deeper, and Tifa just wants to take care of him. The foreground story with Sephiroth and Shinra, and Tifa being rescued with the Promise that Cloud made her still runs deeper than FF6 orCT
snippet.textOriginal: Well, if you think the story in FF7 was overly complex, maybe you should try the Metal Gear storyline. That will get your juices flowing! snippet.textDisplay:
I respect your oppinion but I don't understand how people can vouch for the story and character development in FF7 - the story was overly complex and the characters had very little depth - some love stuff, a character dies, and Vincent was kinda cool - that was it.

Also, a lot of people say they own all the FF games but if they weren't around to play FFVI when it was released, they won't quite 'get it' after going back and playing it retro.
snippet.textOriginal:
I respect your oppinion but I don't understand how people can vouch for the story and character development in FF7 - the story was overly complex and the characters had very little depth - some love stuff, a character dies, and Vincent was kinda cool - that was it.

Also, a lot of people say they own all the FF games but if they weren't around to play FFVI when it was released, they won't quite 'get it' after going back and playing it retro.

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree that FF6 would benefit the most from a remake.

It's really hard for a lot of players to go back and play an old SNES RPG - this was my favorite RPG because I remember playing it when it first came out and it really became a part of my childhood.

I didn't like FF7 at all, though. I didn't care for the story - the plot was convoluted and the individual character development was nothing compared to CT and FF6.

Each to their own though.
snippet.textOriginal:
I agree that FF6 would benefit the most from a remake.

It's really hard for a lot of players to go back and play an old SNES RPG - this was my favorite RPG because I remember playing it when it first came out and it really became a part of my childhood.

I didn't like FF7 at all, though. I didn't care for the story - the plot was convoluted and the individual character development was nothing compared to CT and FF6.

Each to their own though.

snippet.textDisplay: My first RPG was zelda on the NES, I played all the Final Fantasy Series & I liked 7 the best. Combination of the graphics, storyline, and music (not to mention one of the first to use long FMV sequences) made it an epic game.
snippet.textOriginal: My first RPG was zelda on the NES, I played all the Final Fantasy Series & I liked 7 the best. Combination of the graphics, storyline, and music (not to mention one of the first to use long FMV sequences) made it an epic game.

snippet.textDisplay: Good point. My first RPG was Zelda..and my first FF was the first one. And FF7 is still my favorite FF and favorite game of all time for every reason imaginable. If FF6 will stop pissing me off I will beat it on my own someday. Great music though either way. I feel like FF6 would be the FF that would benefit the most from a re-make. It deserves a new light.

snippet.textDisplay:
One of the most memorable tracks from the best console RPG, and best Final Fantasy game to ever be released.

It's funny how the little children love FF7 so much because it was their first RPG - for those of us who were there to see this one hit the shelves, we know better.

snippet.textDisplay: I'll say.  I can appreciate the graphical finesse and realistic character models from the new games, but I just don't feel metrosexual enough to play as some of these characters.  If everyone's super cool then nobody is, you know?  FF Tactics did a superb job of capturing a wider range of personality.  More of that, please.
